ON CHALLIS AND ELLIE ON CATWALK 304
TAKE YOUR MASK TO THE TV SCREEN
BACK TO STARKER, (FLASHLIGHT ON THE GROUND)
TWO MORE DAYS, TWO MORE DAYS
WELCOME TO SANTA MIRA, HOME OF

dialogues.speaker: MAIN TITLE SEQUENCE
dialogues.text: Titles begin to play over a black screen. Suddenly the screen is filled with color! An intense, glowing orange. Electronic. Flickering. A TV screen. The sound of clicking, clattering computer keyboards. A black dot appears in the field of orange, then another and another. These build into the shape of a triangle. TITLES CONTINUE. CAMERA SLOWLY DOLLIES BACK. Another black triangle appears: ‘beside the first. ‘Ey es. The face of a_jack-o-lantern is being electronically "carve into the field of orange. The triangular nose, the jagged smile... The pumpkin shape reverses and rearranges itself on the monitor screen, distorting, enlarging, shrinking, strobing, filling the screen. TITLES OUT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ©) 3. INT./EXT. LONELY GAS STATION - NIGHT 3 OPEN on another TV screen. This one is filled with dramatic shots of Stonehenge.

dialogues.speaker: TV COMMENTATOR
dialogues.text: (V.O. filtered; with British accent) ..-leaving British authorities still baffled and. without any substantial clues nine months after the theft... the Bluestone was one of nineteen, believed to represent the nineteen- year cycle of the moon. It weighs more than five tons, making its disappearance a mystery indeed... PULL BACK to reveal a clean little gas station. The ATTENDANT, JONES, a black man in his forties, sits comfortably at his desk, feet propped up, his nose buried in a boxing magazine. Outside, the rain comes down in sheets.

dialogues.speaker: TV COMMENTATOR
dialogues.text: (continued; V.O.) ) ...but the festival goers seemed none the worse for it, as happy celebrants gathered to welcome in the Autumn season... (a smattering of an Irish jig) Derrick Smith...at Stonehenge.

dialogues.speaker: TV ANCHORMAN
dialogues.text: (vV.0O. filtered; very American) Aaaaaaaand when we come back, Steve will bring us. the weather and Trina sy “will. .bi ne .to-tell. you what, you" “can do ‘about .junk mail. Stay with ‘US...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then, the bright, happy sound of a commercial. Jones glances at the set.

dialogues.speaker: TV SCREEN 4
dialogues.text: A logo spirals out of the video depths and fills the screen:

dialogues.speaker: SILVER SHAMROCK
dialogues.text: Jolly voices begin to sing:

dialogues.speaker: SIL----VER--
dialogues.text: Colorful masks and smiling children spiral onto the screen and dance merrily about: A WITCH, a PUMPKIN and a SKULL.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE 5
dialogues.text: Jones turns back to his magazine. A SHAMROCK VOICE yammers about “horrificly beautiful masks at low, low prices..." In the pouring rain outside, something moves. A FIGURE separates itself from the background and heads toward the station.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man's foot splashes hugely into frame! He staggers doggedly past the gas pumps, gasping for breath. WE FOLLOW. Something dangles from his hand; he drops it. It is a Halloween mask. An orange. pumpkin. The man staggers forward and falls against the station door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The attendant turns, startled. * to the tune of "London Bridge Is Falling Down"  0 10

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man outside (whose name is GRIMBRIDGE) has his face pressed tight against the glass; it is a study in terror and exhaustion. His gray hair is matted. His eyes are wild. Jones opens the door and Grimbridge collapses inward. Jones helps him to the floor.

dialogues.speaker: JONES
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ, man! What happened? Grimbridge stares up at the attendant helplessly. He is emaciated. A week's growth of beard, a cut on his cheek. He slumps into unconsciousness.

dialogues.speaker: JONES
dialogues.text: (continuing) Oh man, don't die here...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The station tow-truck roars to life and backs out into the rain. Grimbridge is slumped against the passenger window. Gears grind, wheels spin and the truck hurtles into the night. PAN WITH IT, finally revealing a_tall thin figure, watching from the shadows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The television plays. commercials..to an empty. room. Upper middle class; suburban. The front door bursts open. JOHN CHALLIS steps in gingerly, rain and lightning behind him. Square-jawed, late thirties; his hair and his clothes are all wrong for the suburbs.

dialogues.speaker: CHALLIS
dialogues.text: (coming in) Anybody home? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: il

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: A commotion from the other end of the house. TWO CHILDREN run into the room carrying forks, napkins, sandwiches, etc. BELLA (9) and WILLIE (10), straight from the dinner table.

dialogues.speaker: BELLA
dialogues.text: (in a jumble) Daddy's here! Daddy's here! Yay, Daddy! Whadja bring us? The children both hit Challis at the same time, nearly knocking him over.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: (off-screen) Children, we leave our food at the table-- Linda comes in. Pretty, well-coiffed. The perfect suburban wife. Except that she and Challis aren't married any more. She looks weary. Challis takes two paper bags from his coat.

dialogues.speaker: BELLA
dialogues.text: Whadja bring us? Lemme see! Lemme see!

dialogues.speaker: CHALLIS
dialogues.text: (to Linda; through the din) Hi. Sorry. Bad timing.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: (phony pleasant) I'm used to it. Remember? . .jxCHALLIS » (to 'the'children) All right, all right! Here! He hands each child a paper bag. ON BELLA AND WILLIE il In unison, they pull Halloween masks from the bags. These aren't the kind on TV. These are smaller, and painted with dull colors. In unison, the children look disappointed.

dialogues.speaker: CHALLIS
dialogues.text: What's wrong? Don't you like them?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Mommy already got us masks...

dialogues.speaker: BELLA
dialogues.text: Silver Shamrock! Look! Challis' face falls. The children drop their gifts and scamper behind the sofa, emerging seconds later wearing two beautiful Silver Shamrock masks! Willie wears a SKULL, his sister a WITCH HEAD. They prance around the room singing the Silver Shamrock song. Linda comes over to Challis. The children settle in front of the TV.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: (softening) Nice try. Challis shrugs, picks up the masks. If it hurts, he doesn't show it much. The phone RINGS. Both children lunge for it.

dialogues.speaker: BELLA
dialogues.text: I'll get it! I'll get it!

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: (getting there first Hello? Yes. Just a moment. (at the kids) Turn that down! She holds the phone out to Challis.

dialogues.speaker: CHILDREN
dialogues.text: They return to their perches in front of the TV, still wearing their masks. Bella turns down the volume just as the Silver Shamrock commercial comes on! Delighted, both children bob and dance to the music.

dialogues.speaker: CHALLIS
dialogues.text: (into phone) Yeah?---when? What's his condition? wc-all right. I'll come on in. (hanging up) I've got to go.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: That's a familiar line.

dialogues.speaker: CHALLIS
dialogues.text: "Bye kids-- But the children are absorbed in their TV-dance. Challis heads for the door. Linda hurries to him. DOLLY IN CLOSE.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: (lowering her voice) John, now listen to me. Saturday morning, 10:30. You're picking them up. Right? No excuses this time?

dialogues.speaker: CHALLIS
dialogues.text: on (irritably) a, Linda...

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: It's been four weeks, nonstop. They're your kids too, dammit. I'm going out of my mind, John, I need some personal space!! You promised me-—-

dialogues.speaker: CHALLIS
dialogues.text: All right. Saturday. And he is gone. Linda stares out into the rain.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: (softly) Bastard. And in the background, the Silver Shamrock jingle tinkles along... CuT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Challis' car slides through the wet night, rounds a curve and slices through the main street of this small California town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Challis drives through the night. The rain lets up; he turns off the wipers. He tries the radio, twisting the dial: Jazz, rock, news, the commercial..."eight more days to Halloween, Halloween, Halloween--" Disgusted, Challis snaps the radio off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See the hospital from some distance away: A couple of stories, modern, stark. A few cars scattered in the gaping parking lot. Challis' car pulls into a special area near the building. He gets out and heads inside. As we PAN with him, we catch a reflection in a nearby car. The tall thin man is watching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Challis comes in. He is met by the HEAD NURSE, (AGNES), a stout woman of middle age. I. should--

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: His condition is stable, but Doctor Castle left early, and I just thought : CHALLIS” Sure. S'fine.’ Where is he? The nurse points ahead. They go up the hallway. WE FOLLOW. -TWO POLICEMEN are standing near a gurney on which Grimbridge is lying. Jones, the station attendant, comes over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lissen. He just walked up out of the rain. I swear to God that's all there was to it...I brought him here... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: One of the policemen hands Challis a form to sign. Challis does so, and the policemen leave. Jones seems relieved. Challis checks Grimbridge over. He appears to be asleep.

dialogues.speaker: CHALLIS
dialogues.text: Got a room for him?

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: Thirteen. Challis begins to push the gurney down the hall.

dialogues.speaker: JONES
dialogues.text: Hey. Can I leave now?

dialogues.speaker: CHALLIS
dialogues.text: Don't see why not. Challis stops the gurney and extends his hand.

dialogues.speaker: CHALLIS
dialogues.text: (continuing; professional courtesy) Thanks for helping him out.

dialogues.speaker: JONES
dialogues.text: Well, I always say...it may be me next time... (AD LIB)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Jones' voice carries OVER.) -The..gurneyhas.stopped' just ;in: frontvof..an- open. do “Looking past Grimbridge's head, "SEE a PATIENT in’ bed, and high up on the wall, a television set. As we watch, the now-familiar happy music starts playing. The Silver Shamrock theme. Grimbridge hears it. His eyes pop open. He feebly raises his head! He moves his mouth, making a croaking sound.  © 20 21

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE 20
dialogues.text: Challis hears this and flies to Grimbridge, leaning in close.

dialogues.speaker: CHALLIS
dialogues.text: Can you hear me? The commercial continues in BACKGROUND. Challis takes no notice.

dialogues.speaker: GRIMBRIDGE
dialogues.text: ({haltingly) They 're----going to----kill us! All of us!!! Grimbridge falls back, trembling.

dialogues.speaker: CHALLIS
dialogues.text: Nurse! Nurse! As the nurse comes running, Jones backs fearfully away, down the hallway and out the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grimbridge sleeps peacefully. The nurse finishes giving him an injection.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: That ought to hold him 'til morning.

dialogues.speaker: CHALLIS
dialogues.text: Great. Who's next?

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: Nobody.. Except. for him it's a quiet. night." .

dialogues.speaker: CHALLIS
dialogues.text: I could use a nap.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: Twenty-two's empty. They go into the hallway.  22 23 24 25

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Challis and the nurse come out and head down the corridor away from CAMERA.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: Pillows are in the cabinet. There's some milk and cookies in the fridge.

dialogues.speaker: CHALLIS
dialogues.text: I think I should have married you, Agnes... He pats her on the behind. She jumps. NURSE . Watch it, buster. I play for keeps. They clown their way down the corridor, their voices receding. Challis goes into a room. The nurse ducks in at her station. After a moment, the tall thin man steps around a corner. He walks quietly across to Grimbridge'’s room. ‘

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the near-darkness, the thin man is no more than a shadow. He glides silently over to the bed.

dialogues.speaker: ON GRIMBRIDGE 24
dialogues.text: Sleeping peacefully, lit dimly by a nearby nightlight. Suddenly a black-gloved hand clamps down across his mouth! His .eyesopen dazedly. His hands feebly claw at the glove;thé sleeve, but his strength is’no-match. for the thin man's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The thin man brings his other hand down toward Grimbridge's face, his thumb and forefinger poised like talons!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stares up in terror, then he clamps his eyes shut as...

dialogues.speaker: HAND
dialogues.text: The thin man brings his hand down and...

dialogues.speaker: GRIMBRIDGE'S FACE, (SFX APPLIANCE)
dialogues.text: The thumb and forefinger penetrate deep into Grimbridge's eye sockets! The hand grips hard, vice-tight.

dialogues.speaker: CUTAWAY
dialogues.text: His feet begin to kick and quiver.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE, (SFX APPLIANCE)
dialogues.text: Suddenly the gloved hand jerks outward with a Sickening CRUNCH. Grimbridge's face changes shape obscenely! Grimbridge stops struggling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The thin man takes a towel from beside the bed and wipes his gloves on it.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: (off-screen) ‘What are you. doing in heré?! WHIP PAN to the door. The nurse has come in, is already crossing to the bed. She sees Grimbridge; her hands fly to her mouth and she screams. The thin man walks calmly past her and out the door.

dialogues.speaker: HALLWAY TO PARKING LOT, (PANAGLIDE)
dialogues.text: Challis springs up out of his nap; he runs into the hallway. The thin man slips out the exit door at the far end. Challis runs down the hallway and into Grimbridge's room.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: He's dead! (pointing) A man--a man just--- Challis runs again. WE FOLLOW. Down the hallway, through a door, down a flight of steps, through another door and into the parking lot. Challis stops and looks around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the distance, the thin man reaches his car. He opens the door and gets inside.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO CHALLIS 34
dialogues.text: He starts running for the car. WE FOLLOW, drawing close.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE THIN MAN 35
dialogues.text: The thin man takes a container and begins to pour liquid on himself, the dashboard, the back seat!

dialogues.speaker: CHALLIS 36
dialogues.text: Challis slows to a stop, mystified.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The thin man strikes a match.

dialogues.speaker: MATCH 38
dialogues.text: For a split second, match-light illuminates the thin man's smooth, blank face. Wet with gasoline!  wo)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a WHOOF, the car's interior roars into flame!

dialogues.speaker: CHALLIS 40
dialogues.text: The wave of heat rocks Challis back on his feet. He stares at the burning car in astonishment and horror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Within seconds, the entire car is an inferno! The gas tank explodes, sending a ball of flame into the air!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People run from surrounding building toward the flaming car, and the mystified doctor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Same angle. POLICE hover about the charred car while TWO MEN IN WHITE COATS pick through the wreckage. A FIRE TRUCK sits nearby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Challis stands at a window, bleary-eyed, still in shock. TWO ATTENDANTS lift Grimbridge's covered body onto a collapsible stretcher. The® SHERIFF;. the CORONER™and.another police OFFICER - talk quietly in the corner. The attendants wheel the stretcher to the door. They are met there by ELLIE GRIMBRIDGE, a pretty woman in her '20's. She is dressed in a suit, obviously prepared to. face the tragedy.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: Is this ---- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The Sheriff crosses hastily over as Ellie starts to lift the sheet.

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF
dialogues.text: Ma'am, I wouldn't...just yet.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: Let's get it over with. Gingerly, the Sheriff lifts the sheet. For just an instant, sheer horror plays across Ellie's face. She holds it in check. Challis watches from his place at the window.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: (continuing) Yes...it's my father. She turns away, breathing deeply. The policeman hands her a cup of water. The coroner begins to pack his bag.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: (continuing) Who did it?

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF
dialogues.text: Some crazy man. Killed himself in the parking lot right after... Drugs, probably. Miss Grimbridge--

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: Is that it? My father's dead because some drug freak was amusing himself?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The whole thing is under. investigation.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: (bitterly) I'll bet!

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF
dialogues.text: Miss Grimbridge, you've had a hard night and you've come a long way. Nobody's sorrier than I am about what you've had to come for. Why (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF
dialogues.text: (continued) don't you get some rest? When you feel better, I'll have some ques- tions for you. And maybe some more answers. The Sheriff pats Ellie's shoulder comfortingly. She straightens herself and walks out. Everyone waits for a pregnant moment. Then the Sheriff sighs hugely.

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF
dialogues.text: (continuing) . All right, boys. Let's clear out. The stretcher is wheeled out. One by one, the others follow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Challis heads wearily toward the exit. A sound stops him. He looks around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Down a side corridor, Ellie is pressed against a wall, half concealed, sobbing quietly.

dialogues.speaker: ON CHALLIS
dialogues.text: He watches helplessly. : FADE OUT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A television set is mounted high up over the bar. A Saturday morning cartoon is playing. There are two people in the bar: Challis and CHARLIE THE BARTENDER, a muscular fellow with a beard and a (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: beer gut. Challis is having bourbon for breakfast. He looks hung over. He winces at the cartoon.

dialogues.speaker: CHALLIS
dialogues.text: Hey Charlie. How about another station? Charlie changes channels, pausing at a preview trailer for the movie "Halloween." An announcer intones promises of "a very special Horrorthon on Halloween night---brought to you by Silver Sham-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: rock!" The familiar tones of the commercial follow..."THREE MORE DAYS TO HALLOWEEN, HALLOWEEN,

dialogues.speaker: CHALLIS
dialogues.text: (continuing) Charlie, come on...

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Whatsamatter? Don't you have any Halloween spirit?

dialogues.speaker: CHALLIS
dialogues.text: No. Charlie finds a football game. He draws himself a beer and settles in to watch. The front door opens and Ellie walks in. She is casually dressed; she looks refreshed and well- rested.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: {coming over) Hi.

dialogues.speaker: CHALLIS
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: My name's Ellie Grimbridge.

dialogues.speaker: CHALLIS
dialogues.text: I know. John Challis.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: I know. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: om

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They sit awkwardly for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: CHALLIS
dialogues.text: I---uh---I'm sorry about your father. I thought about calling or sending flowers or something, but...I figured you'd rather be left alone.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: Thanks. You figured right. (after a moment) Can I ask you something?

dialogues.speaker: CHALLIS
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: Do you do this every morning?

dialogues.speaker: CHALLIS
dialogues.text: No! This is a special occasion!

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: CHALLIS
dialogues.text: The weekend... . (glancing at his watch) It also probably has to do with the fact that I've got to pick up my kids in a little while and I'm not really looking forward to it. (holding up his drink) Get you one?

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: No thanks. Can I ask you something else? Challis nods, amused. Ellie is very attractive; she also knows how to ask questions without being obnoxious.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: (continuing) Did my father say anything to you the night he died? Challis studies his drink for a moment. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CHALLIS
dialogues.text: Yeah. He said, 'tell Ellie I love her.'

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: (moved; rising to go) You're a bad liar...but thanks anyway.

dialogues.speaker: CHALLIS
dialogues.text: Listen. I guess you have a right to know the truth. What he really said was, 'they're going to kill us all.' I hate to tell you this, but your old man was out of his mind. They found him wandering in the rain-- Challis stops. He has gone too far. Ellie fights back tears.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: Could I show you something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The store is dark. Ellie lets herself and Challis in. The front blinds are drawn; "closed" signs hang forlornly in the windows.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: Papa really loved this place. But business was getting bad. I sup- pose you. shopped at the new mall like. everybody: élse.... Challis doesn't answer. He looks around the dusty store. It is a sort of hardware-variety store; a bit of everything. Along one wall is a rack of sports equipment. Next to that, a row of automobile tires. A shelf of toys. Tools, bicycles, clothing, arranged willy-nilly. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: (continuing) He was thinking about closing down. His last letter was all about it. That was three weeks ago. (digging) He wasn't out of his mind then... She picks up an old-looking ledger by the cash register.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: (continuing) The kids were keeping him going. They'd come in after school. He really loved them. Let 'em play with the stuff right in the aisles... like I used to do when I was little. (scanning the ledger) Candy, gum. A bicycle, a basketball, lots of toys...his best customers. (a beat) He kept pretty good records for a crazy man, Doctor--

dialogues.speaker: CHALLIS
dialogues.text: Look, I'm sorry about the comment. Maybe I should go.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: No. I did want to show you something. She picks up an appointment book.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: (continuing; reading) ‘October 18, ° Merchant's council meeting. October 19; ‘football game. October. 20, pick up more masks.' That's the last entry. I think he was referring to these... She goes to a shelf where the Silver Shamrock masks are on display.

dialogues.speaker: CHALLIS
dialogues.text: (wryly) Oh, those things. I know them well. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: They're very popular. According to Papa's ledger, he couldn't stock them fast enough. I did a little detective work. The town where they make these is not too far away. Santa Mira.

dialogues.speaker: CHALLIS
dialogues.text: So what?

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: If he went to the factory to pick up his order--

dialogues.speaker: CHALLIS
dialogues.text: Why wouldn't he just have it sent?

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: Too close to Halloween? Besides, any merchant will tell you if you go to the factory direct, you'll cut your overhead! If Papa went there, then maybe they know some- oa thing I need to know. oS

dialogues.speaker: CHALLIS
dialogues.text: (skeptically) Maybe.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: My father wasn't crazy! And the Sheriff can talk all year about a drug-crazed lunatic running ber- serk and I still don't buy it. I'm surprised anybody does. (a pause) I'm not going:back to :L-A. until I find out what happened. ..maybe they can tell me something in Santa Mira. Challis eyes her for a long moment. Then:

dialogues.speaker: CHALLIS
dialogues.text: Want some company?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: a

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Challis is at a pay phone. In the background, see Ellie's car, a rented Chevy. Double parked, Ellie at the wheel.

dialogues.speaker: CHALLIS
dialogues.text: (into phone) Look Linda, I can't get out of it-- I'm really sorry--aah, just a bunch of doctors talking about boring stuff--Linda, take it easy!---I'll call you Monday---I can't remember the name of the hotel---I've got to go--~'Bye. He hangs up the phone, grabs a six-pack of beer perched on the phone booth, and hops into the car. It glides off into the California afternoon. PAN WITH IT and continue to: ...the show window of an appliance store. Rows and rows of TV sets. And on every one, the Silver Shamrock masks are dancing. The Shamrock theme is playing. The Sham- rock voice is pitching: "GLOWS IN THE DARK! ONLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ellie's car rolls past...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ellie is driving, eating an apple and reading the map at the same time. Challis is sprawled across the seat, his head thrown back, sleeping soundly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Chevy swings off the highway onto a secondary road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car passes a quaint-looking farmhouse and disappears around a curve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car turns onto a lonely back road. distance is the ocean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ellie squints into the sunlight.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: We're almost there...

dialogues.speaker: CHALLIS
dialogues.text: (waking up) Mmmmf...hm?

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: There it is. Deep in the Ellie slows the car to a stop. They both look out.

dialogues.speaker: AFTERNOON MAGIC SHOT
dialogues.text: The sleepy little town of Santa Mira sits nestled in rolling fields. Beyond it, a road leads off to the ocean, some miles away.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: Challis stretches stiffly.

dialogues.speaker: CHALLIS
dialogues.text: That crappy little place is where -all those masks and commercials come from? He settles .back.for another quick cat-nap. . Amused, Ellie drives on.

Looking out the windshield, SEE a big truck round the curve ahead, needing lots of room. It bears down on them. Ellie hits the horn and steers the car onto the shoulder. 55 56 57 58 59  60 61 61a 62 63

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The truck lumbers past, narrowly missing Ellie's car, sending it deep onto the shoulder of the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our two are thrown around a bit.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: (shouting) Jerk! Challis spins around, watching the truck. HIS POV - THROUGH THE BACK WINDOW 61a The truck, featuring a Silver Shamrock logo on its ' side and back, rumbles around the curve and out of sight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car starts onto the road again. Another truck rounds the curve and roars out of town, again taking all the road. Ellie coughs in the dust.

dialogues.speaker: CHALLIS
dialogues.text: Welcome to Santa Mira. Ellie rolls up her window and pulls onto the road again. EXT. “SANTA MIRA OUTSKIRTS - DAY . 63 The car rounds a curve and passes a large sign:

dialogues.speaker: SILVER SHAMROCK
dialogues.text: In the distance, SEE for the first time, the red- brick factory. Smokestacks. A huge Silver Shamrock logo at the highest part of the building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An old but pleasant-looking gas station sits next to a tiny Motel. On the hill behind this sits the Silver Shamrock factory.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RAFFERTY, the very Irish-looking attendant, stands beneath a sign bearing the inscription:

dialogues.speaker: RAFFERTY'S DELUXE
dialogues.text: His eyes follow Ellie's car as it turns a distant corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ellie's car pulls into the town square. It rolls along a row of stores. Most are closed down. No one is on the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ellie and Challis watch the storefronts slide by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A deserted storefront. A uniform shop (factory garb in the window); a neat and tidy little bank, "SHAMROCK SAVINGS"; a grocery, "SHAMROCK STORE"; and so on. Here and there, at windows and in doorways, ruddy Irish faces appear, take along look, then turn away.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: I feel like a goldfish.

dialogues.speaker: CHALLIS
dialogues.text: Company town.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: Irish company town. 64 65 66 67 68 69

dialogues.speaker: HIGH ANGLE
dialogues.text: Ellie's car reaches the end of the row of buildings. It crosses a railroad track, turns in front of an old church and swings back around, one block over. PAN TO FOLLOW, finally revealing a strange object in foreground: Mounted up high on a rooftop, inconspicu- ous, is a small video camera. Its servo-unit whirs, following Ellie's car as it passes.

dialogues.speaker: ON STREET
dialogues.text: The car pulls up and pauses. BOOM DOWN CLOSE as our two look up at something.

dialogues.speaker: LOW ANGLE
dialogues.text: The Silver Shamrock factory looms overhead, bathed in the golden light of the Autumn afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: Looks a little spooky.

dialogues.speaker: CHALLIS
dialogues.text: What do you expect? They make Halloween masks.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: I'm not ready for this. We need a plan.

dialogues.speaker: CHALLIS
dialogues.text: How about this: We drive down that road, ..get some more beer and .go’ to’ ‘the’ beach. “

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: I'm serious!

dialogues.speaker: CHALLIS
dialogues.text: All right, here's one: We go back to that gas station and see if they know anything. We could pose as buyers. Maybe even rent a couple of rooms at that motel... (looking around furtively) Then we'd have someplace to talk without the whole town watching. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: Good point. It's getting late, anyway. Ellie wheels the car down the street toward the gas station. After a moment, a garage door in the factory slides open. A long, silver limousine purrs into the street. Its windows are tinted; no hint of who might be inside. It heads off in the other direction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ellie's car pulls into the station. RAFFERTY comes over from the motel. Now he is all smiles, all charm, all Irish.

dialogues.speaker: RAFFERTY
dialogues.text: Good evenin' to ye! Fill ‘er up?

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: Please.

dialogues.speaker: RAFFERTY
dialogues.text: Aaah...and another grand day it's been in Santa Mira, where the sun smiles down and takes care of its own! He smiles his way to the pumps.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: (under her breath) You've got to be kidding...

dialogues.speaker: CHALLIS
dialogues.text: Welcome to Santa Mira. Dublin West.

dialogues.speaker: RAFFERTY
dialogues.text: (coming back) Just passing through?

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: No, I--uh, my husband and I-- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: A surprised look from Challis.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: (continuing) -7-own a toy store and we've come to pick up some more masks.

dialogues.speaker: RAFFERTY
dialogues.text: Ah, and beauties they are, too! Challis gets enthusiastically into the act. He leans forward and slides his arm onto Ellie's shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: CHALLIS
dialogues.text: You can say that again! Selling like hotcakes, too!

dialogues.speaker: RAFFERTY
dialogues.text: (genuinely pleased) Gocod! Good!

dialogues.speaker: CHALLIS
dialogues.text: Say, pardner. D'you know whether there's a vacancy next door? My wife and I need a place to stay. He smiles a "husband" kind of smile at Ellie, who tries not to crack up.

dialogues.speaker: RAFFERTY
dialogues.text: You've come to the right place. (fishing in his pocket) I own the motel, too! Well, rent it, really. Mr. Cochran owns it, of course. He owns everything around here. But he doesn't try to tell me how to run my business, and I don't try to tell him: how to run his. You see? It ‘all works out! Now! Here we are... He holds out a room-key, dangling from a large green Plastic tab.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door opens, flooding orange light into a small but tidy room. Rafferty comes in, switching on lamps and fluffing up pillows on the lone double bed.

dialogues.speaker: RAFFERTY
dialogues.text: Here 'tis. It's cozy and it's quiet. (stepping into the bathroom) The shower's a good one... HEAR a blast of water, a clattering of pipes. Challis leans in close to Ellie.

dialogues.speaker: CHALLIS
dialogues.text: {softly) Keep him happy for a minute. Challis leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Challis hurries over to the motel office.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO MOTEL ROOM
dialogues.text: Rafferty comes out of the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: RAFFERTY
dialogues.text: No bags?

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: Er...well, the trunk is stuck. (as Rafferty goes outside to help) My husband knows how. to do it, but.uhe went. to register...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rafferty heads toward the trunk of the car.

dialogues.speaker: RAFFERTY
dialogues.text: Got the key? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Ellie comes over, stealing a glance toward the office. She pulls out a key ring with a dozen or so keys.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: (feigning stupidity) I think it's this one...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Challis is leafing hurriedly through the guest register. He finds something of interest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His finger runs down the list of names and finds a signature: HARRY S. GRIMBRIDGE, SIERRA MADRE, CA. ocT. 20.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The trunk pops open. Rafferty smiles.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: My goodness! It certainly isn't stuck anymore, is it? There is one small overnight bag in the trunk. Rafferty grabs it.

dialogues.speaker: RAFFERTY
dialogues.text: Light packers, aren't you?

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: We've had a lot of practice. v Rafferty starts inside with the bag. He hears a car and turns.

dialogues.speaker: RAFFERTY
dialogues.text: Why, there's Mr. Cochran now! He waves and smiles enthusiastically.

dialogues.speaker: ROAD
dialogues.text: The long silver limousine glides by slowly. 78 79 80 81 82  83 84 85 86 87

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seen from inside the limo: Ellie standing, Rafferty waving.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE 84
dialogues.text: She watches the car go by. Rafferty heads inside with Ellie's suitcase.

dialogues.speaker: RAFFERTY
dialogues.text: Great man, Conal Cochran. A true genius...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Again from behind the dark glass, this time tight on Ellie's face. She watches intently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The limousine tails away, past a large Winnebago just pulling into the motel. The vehicle is done up in loud colors. Recreational gear is stacked on top; a boy's bicycle is strapped to the grill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Challis comes out of the office and along the walkway next to the rooms. The Winnebago blasts to a skidding stop just in front of Challis. The bicycle flops onto the ground at his feet with a CRASH. From somewhere inside the van comes a cry of distress: LI'L ‘BUDDY (off-screen) Daddeeeee! !! Challis sets the bike upright. A PORTLY MAN steps from the driver's seat. BUDDY KUPFER. Fortyish.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: (into Winnebago) Aaah, it didn't hurt it! (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: (continuing; coming around to Challis) Hey! Sorry about that. Glad it didn't hit you, and a great big "thank you" for picking it up! You all right? He thrusts out his hand. Buddy's not a bad sort of guy; just a little obnoxious. Challis shakes his hand and starts to pass.

dialogues.speaker: CHALLIS
dialogues.text: No problem.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: Buddy Kupfer. San Diego. That's my wife, Betty-- BETTY KUPFER, a perfect match for Buddy, wearing a bouffant hair-do, climbs out, followed by a miniature Buddy, LI'L BUDDY (12).

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: (continuing) --and right there's little Buddy! It's like the Mickey Mouse Club featuring overweight suburbanites.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Please to meetcha.

dialogues.speaker: LI'L BUDDY
dialogues.text: Is my bike busted? Li'l Buddy runsto his. bike, hops on-it ‘and rides off.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: (screeching) Don't you dare go in the street! You hear me?

dialogues.speaker: CHALLIS
dialogues.text: I've got to go... He backs away, is met by Rafferty. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: RAFFERTY
dialogues.text: Let's check you in now, sir.

dialogues.speaker: CHALLIS
dialogues.text: I filled it out. There's forty dollars under the blotter. That cover it?

dialogues.speaker: RAFFERTY
dialogues.text: Yes! Thank you, sir! Have a pleasant stay. (turning to Buddy) Mr. Kupfer, I presume? Your rooms are waiting.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: O.K., now this is a freebee, right? I mean, we could always stay in the R.V. if we need to-- Challis reaches his door and lingers there, listening.

dialogues.speaker: RAFFERTY
dialogues.text: I assure you, sir, Mr. Cochran o) has taken care of everything!

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: Well that's great! (to Betty, rummaging in the back of the Winnebago) Honey, it's a freebee!

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: (off-screen) What? Challis steps into his room and closes the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Challis leans against the door for a moment. Ellie is sitting neatly on the bed.

dialogues.speaker: CHALLIS
dialogues.text: This place is a zoo.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: I saw Cochran. His car, anyway. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CHALLIS
dialogues.text: You were right. Your old man stayed here on the 20th.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: (standing) Bingo! Then we hit the factory first thing in the morning. (heading toward the bathroom) I'm going to take a shower. -O.K. with you?

dialogues.speaker: CHALLIS
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: What I mean is, this bathroom is so tiny, I'd like to undress out here--

dialogues.speaker: CHALLIS
dialogues.text: Oh! I'll get some air. {at the door) Listen, if it would make you more comfortable, I can sleep in the ear. It's softer than this floor anyway--

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: (softly; coming over) No, no, no... She touches his cheek. Then she plants a tiny kiss there.

dialogues.speaker: ELIIE
dialogues.text: ~ (continuing) I ‘think we can do better than that... Challis thinks this, too. The ice is broken. He watches fondly as she crosses toward the bathroom unbuttoning her blouse. He goes out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Challis enters the street at one end, walking toward the only storefront which is lit up. A neon sign advertizes "LIQUOR." Another one, "BEER."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bathroom door is open. SEE Ellie in the shower through ripple glass. She finishes her shower and steps out, grabbing a towel. Freezing with this scant cover, she runs to the bed, grabs the bedspread and wraps it around herself, shivering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The last hint of daylight leaves the sky. Mercury- vapor lights flicker’ on here and there. Challis comes out of the Liquor store carrying a bottle in a paper sack. He heads back the way he came.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Challis heads down the alley in back of the motel. SUDDENLY a FIGURE looms up out of the darkness beside him! Challis jumps back, startled. He drops the bottle, but it doesn't break.

dialogues.speaker: STARKER
dialogues.text: Ho, mister! Didn't mean to scare you. I just saw that bottle of your'n and thought it looked pretty heavy. Challis picks up the bottle and says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: STARKER
dialogues.text: (continuing) I. ain't got no diseases, and I wager I keep myself as clean as you do. How about a drink? Challis hands over the bottle. Starker leans into it, taking a good long pull. His face catches the light. It is an old face somehow, even though the man couldn't be more than forty. STARKER wears a brimmed hat and a ragged sports jacket. He is the local bum. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: STARKER
dialogues.text: (continuing) Mmmm! God damn. Thank you. He hands the bottle back. Starts to move on.

dialogues.speaker: CHALLIS
dialogues.text: Hey. You know anything about this big wheel named Cochran?

dialogues.speaker: STARKER
dialogues.text: (snorting) Huh! Do I know anything? (dripping sarcasm) Why he made Santa Mira what it is today...a dried-up little pile of nothing! Used to be a pretty nice spot. Good people. Not any more. He bought 'em all. Every one of ‘em. Except me. I didn't have anything to sell. (a pause) I tried to get a job in his place. Let me tell you something. He brought in every damn one of them factory people from the outside. You think he'd hire me? Local boy? No way. Turned me down flat. So I make my money the hard way. You don't have a dollar you could spare, do you?
Challis searches his pocket, finds a dollar. Starker takes it, borrows the bottle again.

dialogues.speaker: STARKER
dialogues.text: (continuing; another slug) Mmm!. God..damn... Thank you. ~ . . (handing the™bottlé back)” All I can tell you mister, is watch out. Seen the TV cameras yet? He's watching you, friend, I guarantee you that. (suddenly shouting)

dialogues.speaker: . CHALLIS
dialogues.text: Take it easy-- Starker staggers a step or two.

dialogues.speaker: STARKER
dialogues.text: It's all right. Don't matter to me. He's probably listening. And if he is, I got one thing to say: This is the last Halloween for that lousy factory of his. They're pulling some wild shit in there, I've heard rumors... (wandering away) +-.this year I'm gon' get me about a case and a half of molotov cock- tails, mister...burn that sumbitch right down...last Halloween for them... Challis watches the man wander off down the alley. He moves off the other way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Challis knocks, comes in. The light is low, romantic; Ellie is brushing her hair by the heater, still draped in the bedspread. A small portable radio is playing. Challis has found some ice outside. He sets every- thing down, makes himself a drink while he watches Ellie. She brushes her hair and watches him back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Starker comes along, whistling. The trestle is thirty feet high. Its dark timbers cut zig-zag patterns. in the-night. sky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through the timbers, on Starker walking, whistling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Starker stumbles, walks on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Starker approaches CAMERA. Suddenly a harsh bright light bathes his face!

dialogues.speaker: STARKER
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: STARKER'S MIDSECTION 98
dialogues.text: Two black-gloved hands appear from behind and clamp Starker's arms to his sides. WHAP-WHAP!

dialogues.speaker: FLASHLIGHT/STARKER'S FACE 99
dialogues.text: A powerful flashlight is shoved up close to Starker's face. It is held by a black-gloved hand. Scrutinizing.

dialogues.speaker: STARKER
dialogues.text: (suddenly sober) Hey fellas, I was just kidding! You know that, don't you? Kidding!

dialogues.speaker: ON STARKER 100
dialogues.text: WHAM! He is forced suddenly to his knees .by the man in back. The man in front drops the flashlight into the weeds. These men, seen dimly, are wearing neat gray suits. Like the other assassin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: High angle looking down onto the bed. Ellie reclines languidly into frame,.letting. the bedspread, fall away. Challis follows, head and hand on her stomach. Kissing. The radio music is perfect...

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO STARKER, (FLASHLIGHT ON THE GROUND)
dialogues.text: A closeup. The black gloves reach in and grab him firmly around each ear. The hands begin to tug. Starker's neck begins to stretch! Starker tries to scream!  we, 103 104 105

dialogues.speaker: MOTEL 103
dialogues.text: Ellie and Challis making love.

dialogues.speaker: THE RAILROAD TRESTLE 104
dialogues.text: Backlit by the flashlight, the three figures are nothing more than abstract silhouettes as... The man in front gives a sudden heave and pulls Starker's head off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dark and quiet now. Challis and Ellie lying quietly in each other's arms. Radio playing softly. DOLLY IN. Then...the commercial comes on: "TWO MORE

dialogues.speaker: DAYS TO HALLOWEEN, HALLOWEEN, HALLOWEEN--"
dialogues.text: It's too absurd. Laughing in disbelief, Challis snakes out his hand and shuts it off.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: (lazily) It's late...

dialogues.speaker: CHALLIS
dialogues.text: It's early, you mean. Get some sleep.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: CHALLIS
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: I wouldn't have tried all this if you hadn't come along. (a pause) Thanks. They kiss and settle in for sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Challis is sprawled across the bed, his arms dangling to the floor. Ellie wakes up frowning. She looks at her watch on the night table.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: Damn! (holding her nose, talking announcerese) Calling Dr. Challis...calling Dr. Challis... (sees him stirring) It's already past noon.

dialogues.speaker: CHALLIS
dialogues.text: The doctor isn't in right now...

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: (kissing his ear) No? He opens one eye and wraps his free arm around her. She smiles and rolls against him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (CLOSEUP - SILVER SHAMROCK CLOCK)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 3:30 on the clock. Ellie's car pulls up and our two get out, still looking sleepy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Challis and Ellie walk up to a door marked "OFFICE." They:go inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our two go down a short hallway and into a neutral office area. On the far wall is a large Silver Shamrock logo. Above it hangs a photo-portrait of a silver-haired, fatherly-looking gentleman (COCHRAN). A broad counter divides the receiving area from the office area, where a handful of OFFICE WORKERS go about their business. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: A WOMAN is at the counter, heatedly talking to the HEAD SECRETARY. MARGE GUTTMAN is in her thirties; a little brassy, a wide, quick smile. She isn't smiling right now.

dialogues.speaker: MARGE
dialogues.text: --well I just don't see any excuse for it! I called my order in day before yesterday! They said it would be ready!

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY
dialogues.text: Madam, please calm down--

dialogues.speaker: MARGE
dialogues.text: I've got a business to run! If you think I'm going to stay here tonight just because somebody shuffled the wrong papers then you got another think coming, sister!

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY
dialogues.text: I assure you we're doing what we can--

dialogues.speaker: MARGE
dialogues.text: Well try to do it just a little bit faster, all right? The secretary turns to Ellie and Challis. A rosy smile pops onto her face. Marge scowls and lights up a cigarette, puffing at it furiously.

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY
dialogues.text: May I.help you?

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: Yes. I--my father put in an order last week. Something's gone wrong. We never received it.

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY
dialogues.text: What firm do you represent?

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: Grimbridge's, Sierra Madre. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY
dialogues.text: Just a moment. The secretary moves off toward a bank of file cabinets.

dialogues.speaker: MARGE
dialogues.text: {to Ellie) Good luck. Their masks may be fabulous, but they're not too swift up here. (tapping her temple) I'm going to have to stay here tonight, I just know it. In that cruddy motel. It's the only place within fifty miles. The secretary returns with a yellow form.

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY
dialogues.text: There must be some mistake, dear. Our records show that Mr. Grim- bridge himself picked that order up on the 2lst. Here's his signature... Ellie scans the slip.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: Well. Er--thank you. Do you-- remember that transaction?

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY
dialogues.text: As a matter of fact, I do! He was in a hurry, like-- (a glance at Marge) ~--like everyone else, this time of year.. elieve..Red- helped ’ him load his“car. " .

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: Red?

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY
dialogues.text: Yes. Would you like to speak with him? She hits a button on the counter. Immediately, too immediately, a RED-HEADED MAN comes through a door in back. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Og 109

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY
dialogues.text: (continuing) Red, these people lost an order. Did you load this one?

dialogues.speaker: RED
dialogues.text: (scanning the sheet) Sure did. Last week. Man in an old green station wagon.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: That's right! Did he say where he was going?

dialogues.speaker: RED
dialogues.text: No.ma'am. He headed out to the north, though...I remember that.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: . (disappointed) Thank you. She turns away.

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY
dialogues.text: Are you going to make another order, ma'am?

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: No. (to Challis) Let's go. There is a’ commotion in the hallway. Buddy, Betty and Li'l Buddy Kupfer burst in. They are dressed in their Sunday best. Buddy wears a smile as big as Texas.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: Well! How you doin'? (to secretary) Buddy Kupfer and family... (proudly) --here to see Mr. Cochran.

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY
dialogues.text: (beaming) Yes, Mr. Kupfer! Welcome! I'11 tell Mr. Cochran you're here! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MARGE
dialogues.text: Tell him I'm here too, lady! Tell him I'd like some service! The secretary moves off.

dialogues.speaker: LI'L BUDDY
dialogues.text: Whenna we get to see 'em makin' the masks?

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: Real soon, little Buddy, real soon.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: I'm hungry...

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: (to Challis) I've had enough. Let's get out of here.

dialogues.speaker: CHALLIS
dialogues.text: Wait a minute... There is a stir at the back of the office. The typewriters fall silent. A door opens and in walks CONAL COCHRAN, an incredibly kind looking gentleman in a blue suit, white shirt and red tie. He is followed closely by TWO YOUNG IRISHMEN with rather blank faces, also in suits, these of gray. The effect is of legitimate, wealthy, corporate ower. But the gray suits are familiar. Last night. Starker's killers! Cochran moves easily through the office and up to the front counter. His voice has an Irish lilt to it. * : 7

dialogues.speaker: COCHRAN
dialogues.text: So this is Buddy Kupfer, and his lovely family! (to the room) My friends, Mr. Kupfer has sold more Silver Shamrock masks this year by far, than anyone else on earth! The office workers break into applause. Cochran reaches out for Buddy's hand. Buddy is speechless, (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: -_ 109 CONTINUED
dialogues.text: in total awe of Cochran, button-burstingly proud. Betty beams; Li'l Buddy picks his nose.

dialogues.speaker: COCHRAN
dialogues.text: (continuing) Silver Shamrock likes to do a little something special for its champion salesman each year, and that's why 4 you've been invited here. I hope your stay is a merry one, so I do!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (moved) ' Thank you! Thank you sir! , Again, the applause. Ellie and Challis exchange glances. It's a little bit strange. Cochran ; suddenly fastens his gaze on them, and on Marge.

dialogues.speaker: COCHRAN
dialogues.text: 1 And to my other friends, Ms. ) Guttman, correct?-— ' He goes to Marge, kisses her hand; she is instantly won over. He turns to Ellie and Challis.

dialogues.speaker: COCHRAN.
dialogues.text: (continuing) i --and Mr. and Mrs.--

dialogues.speaker: CHALLIS
dialogues.text: Smith.

dialogues.speaker: COCHRAN
dialogues.text: (amused) Smith; of course---my apologies for the confusion and the delays. i I. know you understand. i (an emphatic nod from Marge) It's the season, isn't it? But since you've lost time, and probably money through no fault of your own, I want you to know that you may take delivery of your full orders absolutely free of charge. It's on me. Marge gasps. The office-workers applaud again. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: (reverently; to Betty) Is he incredible, or what?

dialogues.speaker: COCHRAN
dialogues.text: And now, Mr. Kupfer, a guided tour for you and your family. And of course, our other friends-- (a sweeping gesture toward Marge, Ellie and Challis) --with your permission.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: Oh, of course! By all means!

dialogues.speaker: COCHRAN
dialogues.text: Shall we? One of the Graysuits holds open a door in the counter. One by one, the procession files through the office, past the beaming workers and through the door in back. Ellie and Challis fall in and follow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looking down a long, spacious room, SEE dozens of male and female MASKWORKERS standing at long tables, making the three Silver Shamrock masks: WITCH, SKULL and JACK-O-LANTERN. The place is strangely quiet; just the dull presence of a large room. Its light is constant; day or night. Our group enters through a door at one end. Little Buddy .is- first; he runs-~ ahead. NEW ANGLE lll Cochran takes the lead, talking easily, enjoying himself.

dialogues.speaker: COCHRAN
dialogues.text: --the latex is heated and poured, then allowed to cool in the mold. Excess poured off, then it's just a lot of details, painting and packaging...
The process of maskmaking is illustrated by a series of shots: Heating, pouring, cooling, trimming, painting-- Cochran leads everyone through a small door at the other end of the factory.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very low light. A series of display cases. A wall full of monster masks. A door marked "PRIVATE". Little Buddy darts through, ahead of the others. . He gives everything a quick look, .then moves on ahead, playing with his computer game. The others enter and spread out, as if at a museum. Here, a cluster of wonderful looking mechanical toys. There, a display case full of gag novelties. Buddy and Challis find themselves grouped together.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: Oh, wow...this is it. This is really it. Hall of Fame time...

dialogues.speaker: CHALLIS
dialogues.text: What's famous?

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: You really don't know? Conal Cochran? The all-time genius of the practical joke? He invented sticky toilet paper!

dialogues.speaker: CHALLIS
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: You must know the Dead Dwarf gag. The Soft Chainsaw? All his!

dialogues.speaker: CHALLIS
dialogues.text: (phony reverence) Gee, I didn't know... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: “HALLOWEEN 3" 114

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: He manufactured the best boomer cushion in the business. It made a great sound-- (makes Bronx cheer) --really loud and convincing. The man has always paid attention to detail. Mechanical toys, masks... (going to a mask) Look at that paint job. Boy, I'm glad little Buddy's getting a chance to see these-- (braying)

dialogues.speaker: AT THIS STUFF
dialogues.text: (to Challis) : It's a real shame Mr. Cochran doesn't make this stuff anymore, but it wasn't paying off. Took a lot of guts for him to cut his losses and find something with some profit in it.

dialogues.speaker: CHALLIS
dialogues.text: The masks?

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: You bet. The Big Halloween Three. Restrict the choices, lower the price, go for quality, simplify. Saturation advertising. Our a4 is on every major radio and TV station in the country! It's incredible!

dialogues.speaker: . CHALLIS
dialogues.text: Yeah... It is. .

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: You know what? By Halloween night, there'll be fifty million Silver Shamrock masks on fifty million heads out there. That's--- (groping) : that's unprecedented! Great to be on a winning team, isn't it? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: “HALLOWEEN 3" REV. 4/4/82 47B. 114

dialogues.speaker: CHALLIS
dialogues.text: (uneasily) Yeah. Theyfollow the others through another doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Challis and Buddy come around a corner into a spacious receiving room. They stop and look. PAN AROUND. The beaming office workers have gathered here along with Cochran Marge and the others. A large cake and a punch bowl sit waiting. Decorations hang from the ceili Cochran holds a large ceremonial plaque out to Buddy.

dialogues.speaker: COCHRAN
dialogues.text: Buddy Kupfer, it is my pleasure to present you with this year's Silver Shamrock Halloween Sales Award. Congratulations. Buddy steps forward, speechless. The office workers applaud. Betty beams. Li'l Buddy picks his nose. Ellie backs toward the Display Room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ellie comes in. The room is empty. She moves quickly over to a door marked "PRIVATE". She opens it. A.Graysuit is standing there. Looking at her.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: Whoops. My mistake... She closes the door again. Another Darksuit separates himself from the shadows at the other end of the room.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: (continuing) Have a nice day... She heads back toward the Main Room.

dialogues.speaker: MAIN ROOM
dialogues.text: The office workers are making merry. Buddy is shaking Cochran's hand. Betty fishes in her purse and comes up with a camera. She hands it to a Graysuit, who obligingly snaps a picture.

dialogues.speaker: COCHRAN
dialogues.text: Oh! And one more thing... {taking an envelope from his coat) A. small token of my appreciation. He hands the envelope to Buddy. There is a game-show sort of atmosphere prevalent as Buddy opens the envelope and gasps at what he sees. A check.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: Five thousand dollars!

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Oh my God... Betty throws her arms around Cochran's neck. More applause from the office-workers. Marge joins in. Challis and Ellie stand awkwardly to one side, staring at the spectacle, trading mystified glances.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a spacious area where a few MASKWORKERS stand, packing the masks in cardboard boxes. Our -group:enters .and passes through... Cochran.:is.the center of the Kupfer family's attention: Li'l Buddy rides Cochran piggy-back. Buddy and Betty walk arm in arm, smiling beatifically.

dialogues.speaker: LI'L BUDDY
dialogues.text: I want a mask! Can I have a mask?

dialogues.speaker: COCHRAN
dialogues.text: Just what I had in mind for you, my young friend--

dialogues.speaker: LI'L BUDDY
dialogues.text: (pointing) I want that one! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: COCHRAN
dialogues.text: (laughing) Oh, no no no no no! These masks haven't been. through final pro- cessing! This way... He moves off.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: What's final processing? ' Everyone follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a maze of activity here: YARDMEN and DRIVERS scurry about, moving case after case of masks onto pallettes, onto trucks, onto converyors, onto fork lifts. Loaded trucks pull out of the yard, bound for the outside world.

dialogues.speaker: LOADING DOCK 116A
dialogues.text: Cochran and the others come out onto the platform. They are surrounded by activity. A truck is loaded. ‘ It pulls away. Boxes are stacked everywhere. Cochran nods at one of the Graysuits, who walks over to a stack of boxes outside a set of double doors marked NO ADMITTANCE. There is something about the door, the entranceway, that seems sinister, forbidding. The Graysuit picks up one of the boxes here and tears it open. Cochran, Li'l Buddy and Buddy come over. The Graysuit hands a Jack-o-lantern mask to Cochran. Buddy points at the double doors.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: This final processing, Mr. Cochran-- what is it?

dialogues.speaker: COCHRAN
dialogues.text: Oh, a bit o' this and a bit o' that...quality inspection, the seal of approval... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: “HALLOWEEN 3" REV. 4/4/82 49a.

dialogues.speaker: 116A CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He shows Buddy the round Silver Shamrock seal on the mask. Then Cochran turns to Little Buddy.

dialogues.speaker: 116B LI'L BUDDY/COCHRAN
dialogues.text: In sharp foreground SEE the back of the mask as Cochran pulls it onto the boy's head. The seal is clearly visible now, in its place at the base of the neck-flap. Cochran surveys Li'l Buddy with delight. The old man claps his hands like a child. Li'l Buddy runs around 'scaring' people. Buddy points at the door again.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: (to Cochran) So can we take'a look?

dialogues.speaker: COCHRAN
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. Part of the inspec- tion process involved highly volatile chemicals. I'd hate to put anyone in danger.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: Oh sure. I understand.

dialogues.speaker: COCHRAN
dialogues.text: I do hope you and your family will join me tomorrow for breakfast. We'd like your opinion on some of our sales material.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: My opinion? (flattered) Sure! Any time!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Challis is off to himself, looking the operation over. (CONTINUED)
cy 117 CONTINUED: 117 Ellie and Marge have paired off to one side, watching in the distance as Cochran makes some point to the others.

dialogues.speaker: MARGE
dialogues.text: What a’ character. Did you know he's supposedly one of the richest men in the country? And he got there selling cheap gags and halloween masks...there's hope for me. I also heard that he lives here. Right in the factory.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: How strange. - What-- Something catches Ellie's eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A forklift is driving into a dark garage. As the door is sliding shut, SEE just a glimpse of a green station wagon...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ellie's eyes widen.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: That was my father's--

dialogues.speaker: MARGE
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: My God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She starts running toward the garage.

dialogues.speaker: ON COCHRAN 120
dialogues.text: Cochran sees her first. He tilts his eyebrows and the Graysuits run after her.

dialogues.speaker: THE OTHERS 121
dialogues.text: Challis, the others see her running. Confusion.

dialogues.speaker: THE GARAGE
dialogues.text: Ellie is nearly there when the Graysuits catch up with her. The car,

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: dammit! She stops, checking herself.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO COCHRAN
dialogues.text: The car is-- He eyes her with new interest.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO ELLIE
dialogues.text: She stops fighting. They grab her firmly but politely. Behind her, workmen busy themselves locking the garage. One of the Graysuits points apologetically to a large sign above the garage door:

dialogues.speaker: "STRIC
dialogues.text: ‘TLY NO Ellie composes herself and walks away from the garage, back to Challis.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: The sun drops into the distant ocean, bathing the motel roof in brilliant orange FOR a moment, then darkness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Challis is pacing. Ellie. is perched on the bed, visibly upset. I saw it.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: I know

dialogues.speaker: CHALLIS
dialogues.text: I saw it. Then I think it's time for the Marines. I'm scared.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: I think we should leave. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CHALLIS
dialogues.text: All right. I've got no objections to that. Let me go call the Sheriff back home first. He can put us on the right track. This place falls under somebody's jurisdiction--

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: Hurry... Challis goes out the door. Ellie follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Challis hurries to the office. Ellie lingers near her car.

dialogues.speaker: MARGE
dialogues.text: (off-screen) Mrs. Smith? Mrs. Smith! Ellie remembers her alias and spins around. Marge is standing in the doorway of another room. Ellie comes over.

dialogues.speaker: MARGE
dialogues.text: (continuing) I just had to talk to somebody. May I show you something? She leads Ellie inside. INT. MARGE’S ROOM - NIGHT 128 Like the other motel room, only a different color. Marge. holds up a. disfigured witch-mask.

dialogues.speaker: . MARGE
dialogues.text: I sat this on the radiator. Dumb thing to do. It ruined the mask-- but then this little logo thing, the Silver Shamrock trademark, you know, it came off in my hand. And there's something very strange about it... She holds it under the desk-light, the only light source in the room.

dialogues.speaker: SILVER SHAMROCK TRADE-SEAL
dialogues.text: The front of the seal. Then Marge's hands turn it over. On the back, planted dead center, is a micro- chip, visibly complex and colorful.

dialogues.speaker: MARGE
dialogues.text: (continuing) Know anything about electronics?

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: No. Marge seats herself at the desk.

dialogues.speaker: MARGE
dialogues.text: Well, all I know is, this thing is incredibly complex and sophisticated. What I don't know is, what does it ‘do? What is it for! And why is there one on each and every Halloween mask? (gesturing at a pile of masks on the bed) I don't get it... Ellie fights off a wave of dread and fear.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: Perhaps my--husband might know more about this. I'll get him.

dialogues.speaker: MARGE
dialogues.text: Great. And see if you can round up some batteries. These are too weak. She holds up her transister radio. She has pulled the batteries out of it and stacked them on the desk. ./ ELLIE ee! & Batteries?

dialogues.speaker: MARGE
dialogues.text: Hell, I don't know what I'm doing. Thought maybe I could get it to lay, or light up, or whatever it's supposed to do--

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: Marge, be careful. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MARGE
dialogues.text: Oh, believe me, it's probably some stupid mixup. I told you before, at the lower levels of that organization, they're just out to lunch.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: I'll be right back. Ellie hurries out. Marge turns to the trade-seals...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Challis is on the telephone, grimacing.

dialogues.speaker: CHALLIS
dialogues.text: Well try again! Thank you. Ellie comes in.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: Any luck?

dialogues.speaker: CHALLIS
dialogues.text: Not so far--wait a minute-- (a beat) Hello, Sheriff? Dr. John Challis. Yes. We've got something here...

dialogues.speaker: MARGE'S ROOM
dialogues.text: Marge puts on her reading glasses, studies the trade-seals, picks up the battery... Suddenly pulls. a‘hairpin.from*her-hair.. ‘She begins to ‘bend and twist it against ‘the batteries: =

dialogues.speaker: CHALLIS
dialogues.text: (into phone) All right. We'll do that. Thanks. After we get to Leytonville. Right. Anything else? 129 130 131 132

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: . Marge bites her lip in fierce concentration. Hair- pins, battery terminals; the trade-seal slips from her fingers.

dialogues.speaker: MARGE
dialogues.text: Damn! She tries again, blinking fiercely to clear her vision.

dialogues.speaker: MARGE'S HANDS, (SFX)
dialogues.text: Marge's hands push the battery-charged hairpin against the trade-seal. There is a tiny sound and a tiny spark.

dialogues.speaker: MARGE
dialogues.text: A small, brilliant light emanates from the trade- seal. Suddenly a blinding streak sears from the seal o directly into Marge's forehead!!!

dialogues.speaker: MOTEL OFFICE 136
dialogues.text: Challis hangs up the phone.

dialogues.speaker: CHALLIS
dialogues.text: Odd...

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: What? CHALLIS.”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He said there. was’ a mixup of some kind. The body of that man who burned up in the parking lot... ‘ They examined the wrong specimen. 4 Got him mixed up with the dash- board or something--all they had was a big pile of silicone.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: Can this wait? What did he say about the police? e (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CHALLIS
dialogues.text: He said to get the hell out and phone it in from Leytonville.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: I think we should tell Marge. She's uncovered some kind of microchip on every mask. It's the strangest thing... They go out. '

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marge's door is slightly ajar. There is a strange sound coming from within, a faraway, barely-human wail... Our two come across the parking lot on the run, Ellie in the lead. She pauses at the door.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: Marge? They go inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sitting in the chair by the desk is a living horror that was formerly Marge. The desk lamp lies on the floor, overturned in the first convulsions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her eyeballs are the color of blood, the pupils gone. Her mouth is wide open, distended. forward and torn’ ragged by the blasting exhalation that has actually napped off eth -and.-rendered lips. into.stréaming oo ae laments: And: from this “opening. comes ‘the steady, : subhuman shriek...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tiny rivulets of blood seep from her pores; she is still wearing her glasses. The frame has melted from intense heat. They droop on what is left of her nose. There is no intake of breath, just the dreadful exhaust-roar of her tattered voice. On and on and on... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: For moments, Challis and Ellie can only stare in horror. Ellie's hands fly up to her own face, pulling at her skin.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: Dear God, dear God...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Challis races out of Marge's room. CAMERA PANAGLIDES WITH HIM along the darkened motel rooms. He stops at Buddy's door. Knocks.

dialogues.speaker: CHALLIS
dialogues.text: Buddy! No answer. Challis quickly moves on. Up to the office door. He bangs on it furiously. And glances over his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: THE FACTORY 140
dialogues.text: Across the street, the factory. Lights on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rafferty opens the door. Looks out at.Challis.

dialogues.speaker: CHALLIS
dialogues.text: Get an ambulance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What...?

dialogues.speaker: CHALLIS
dialogues.text: There's a woman down there--she's had some kind of...seizure or something...

dialogues.speaker: RAFFERTY
dialogues.text: Seizure? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CHALLIS
dialogues.text: She's been-- For God's sake, man--

dialogues.speaker: RAFFERTY
dialogues.text: Bad, is she?

dialogues.speaker: CHALLIS
dialogues.text: Just get help! Challis starts back toward Marge's room.

dialogues.speaker: RAFFERTY
dialogues.text: There's no hospital.

dialogues.speaker: CHALLIS
dialogues.text: What? There must be!

dialogues.speaker: RAFFERTY
dialogues.text: Only the clinic, that's all. Over in White Springs. About fifteen miles. That's all there is--

dialogues.speaker: CHALLIS
dialogues.text: Call them!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ellie stands near Marge. Staring at her. The fierce hissing wail has died away, as if Marge's condition has gone into a secondary phase. Her body is still racked with a steady shuddering but it is less violent. Faint, formless croaks come from her

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: throat. CLOSE-ON ELLIB go AN ee ee AB Staring.

dialogues.speaker: MARGE 144
dialogues.text: Something moves at Marge's mouth. Two small, arachnid-like legs push their way out through Marge’s lips.  145 146 147 148 149 150 59.

dialogues.speaker: ON ELLIE
dialogues.text: Speechless. Horrified.

dialogues.speaker: MARGE
dialogues.text: A_small, glistening spider crawls out of Marg mouth!

dialogues.speaker: ON ELLIE
dialogues.text: She turns and bolts for the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ellie slams directly inte Challis outside the door.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: John...Look at her mouth! Rafferty ambles up. They look in the door.

dialogues.speaker: MARGE'S ROOM
dialogues.text: Marge sits motionless now. Looking dead. The spider is_gone from her ruined lips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rafferty peers in at.Marge. And reacts, but not quite as sharply as we might expect.

dialogues.speaker: RAFFERTY
dialogues.text: Whatever did it?.. Burns? It must have been -burns-- .

dialogues.speaker: CHALLIS
dialogues.text: Have you ever seen anything like this before?

dialogues.speaker: RAFFERTY
dialogues.text: A couple. From the factory. They said it was chemical poisoning...

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: No, no...This thing came out of her mouth... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Rafferty looks around.

dialogues.speaker: RAFFERTY
dialogues.text: Not to worry. They're already coming. Challis and Ellie turn.

dialogues.speaker: THE FACTORY 151
dialogues.text: Several cars emerge from the factory. They move quickly toward the motel.

dialogues.speaker: RAFFERTY
dialogues.text: They'1l take care of her. Better than bouncin' her all over the countryside...

dialogues.speaker: CHALLIS
dialogues.text: Are you going to call that ambulance?

dialogues.speaker: RAFFERTY
dialogues.text: I'm telling you, she'll be in better hands...

dialogues.speaker: CHALLIS
dialogues.text: Then I'll do it.

dialogues.speaker: RAFFERTY
dialogues.text: (shrugs) Phone's in the office.

dialogues.speaker: CHALLIS
dialogues.text: (to Ellie) Get your things. Quick. Challis and Ellie move off. Leaving Rafferty by Marge's door.

dialogues.speaker: RAFFERTY
dialogues.text: It's a company town. They provide everything...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Challis strides into the dark room. Up to the phone on the counter. A TV set is on in the darkness. A Silver Shamrock commercial is on. The dancing masked figures.

dialogues.speaker: KEEP YOUR EYES ON THE TV SCREEN...
dialogues.text: Challis picks up the phone and dials. Behind him in the b.g. we see the cars from the factory pull into the motel parking lot.

dialogues.speaker: CHALLIS
dialogues.text: (into phone) Operator, this is an emergency. A CLICK on the line.

dialogues.speaker: RECORDED TELEPHONE VOICE
dialogues.text: (over telephone) I'm sorry, but we cannot complete your call as dialed. Please hang up and dial again. This is a recording. - Challis punches the cradle. Dials again. The lights from the factory cars swish through the office windows.

dialogues.speaker: RECORDED TELEPHONE VOICE
dialogues.text: {over telephone) I'm sorry, but we cannot complete your call... Challis slams down the phone. CHALLIS' POV - ‘A JACK-O-LANTERN MASK 154 In the darkness of the room, a JACK-O-LANTERN mask lies on a chair. Challis' hand reaches in and grabs it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Challis steps out of the office. Walks quickly down toward Marge's room. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Several cars have pulled in. GRAYSUITS and TECHNICIANS get out and converge around Marge's room. (We will see more of the Technicians later. They are dressed some- what like doctors.) Rafferty points inside Marge's room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ellie is throwing things into her suitcase. She's erying. Terrified.

dialogues.speaker: CHALLIS
dialogues.text: Forget it. Just bring the car keys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Challis moves from his room down to Marge's room. Several Technicians carry Marge out of her room on a stretcher. They move her quickly into a dark van. The van pulls away from the motel just as the long Cadillac silently pulls in. Cochran gets out. One of the Graysuits comes over.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSUIT
dialogues.text: (softly) We had a misfire. Cochran nods to him, then moves to Challis.

dialogues.speaker: COCHRAN
dialogues.text: Evening, Mister Smith.....I'm: sure 2 “everything will be fines: “sorry: ~ 5 for any alarm this may have--

dialogues.speaker: CHALLIS
dialogues.text: What is this? Challis holds up the Jack-O-Lantern mask. Points to the Silver Shamrock seal on the back.

dialogues.speaker: COCHRAN
dialogues.text: (smiling) The seal of approval. Weren't you listening today? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: i)

dialogues.speaker: QO
dialogues.text: “HALLOWEEN 3"

dialogues.speaker: CHALLIS
dialogues.text: It's full of micro-electronics. And somehow it kills, doesn't it?

dialogues.speaker: COCHRAN
dialogues.text: Mister Smith...

dialogues.speaker: CHALLIS
dialogues.text: It blew up in Marge's face... went off, did whatever it does. But you've seen what it can do before, haven't you? Challis tosses the mask at Cochran. It slaps against his leg and drops to the ground. Cochran smiles a benevolent, innocent smile.

dialogues.speaker: COCHRAN
dialogues.text: Mister Smith, you've been under some strain, I-can see that. Now if you'll come with me to the factory, I'll show you the entire process. I think you'll see--

dialogues.speaker: CHALLIS
dialogues.text: You're putting these things in the hands of children! Why?

dialogues.speaker: COCHRAN
dialogues.text: I'll show you. Challis backs away.

dialogues.speaker: CHALLIS
